review.title: Overview: Generalizations of Multi-Agent Path Finding to Real-World Scenarios
review.abstract: Multi-agent path finding (MAPF) is well-studied in artificial intelligence, robotics, theoretical computer science and operations research. We discuss issues that arise when generalizing MAPF methods to real-world scenarios and four research directions that address them. We emphasize the importance of addressing these issues as opposed to developing faster methods for the standard formulation of the MAPF problem.
histories: In IJCAI-16 Workshop on Multi-Agent Path Finding
review.COMMENTS: In IJCAI-16 Workshop on Multi-Agent Path Finding

metadata.title: Overview: Generalizations of Multi-Agent Path Finding to Real-World Scenarios

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The task of (standard) MAPF is to find the pathways for multiple agents in a given diagram from their current wells to their targets without colliding with other agents, while optimizing a cost function at the same time. Existing MAPF methods are used, for example, to achieve reductions in satisfaction problems, integer linear programming or response to programming [Yu and LaValle, 2013b et al., 2013; Surynek, 2015] or to use suboptimal search methods [Silver, 2005; Sturtevant and Buro, 2006; Wang and Botea, 2008; Standley, 2010; Standley and Korf, 2011; Wang and Botea, 2011; Luna and Bekris, 2011; Sharon et al., 2013; Barer et al.

sections.heading: 2 Combined Target Assignment and Path Finding (TAPF) for Teams of Agents
sections.text: Each agent in a team must be assigned a target, which is assigned to his team, so that agents "paths from their current wells to their destination optimize a cost function. For example, in a Kiva warehouse system, the drive units that move warehouse pods from inventory stations to warehouses are grouped into one team, because each of them must be assigned an available warehouse location. Previous MAPF methods assumed that each agent was assigned a target in advance through some targeting procedures, but to achieve optimum results, we have formulated TAPF, which links goal assignment and path finding problems and defines a common goal for both. In TAPF, agents are divided into teams. Each team receives the same number of unique targets as there are agents in the team. TAPF's job is to assign goals to agents and plan conflict-free paths for agents.

sections.heading: 3 Package-Exchange Robot Routing (PERR) and New Complexity Results for MAPF
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to move to another world, in which they are able to move, in which they are able to move, and in which they see themselves able to move.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Maxim Likhachev and Michael Phillips for helpful discussions and Ariel Felner, Guni Sharon and Maxim Barer for the CBS and ECBS (w) source code we used in our experiments, which were supported by NSF grant numbers 1409987 and 1319966.

sections.heading: 4 Exploitation of Problem Structure and Predictability of Motions
sections.text: Agents share their workspaces with people, and the consistency of their movements and the resulting predictability of their movements are important for the safety of people, which is not taken into account by the existing MAPF methods. This motivates us to exploit the problem structure of the given MAPF cases and to design a scheme that encourages agents to move along the edges provided by the user (so-called highways) [Cohen et al., 2015]. We use motorways in the context of a simple inflation scheme based on the ideas of experience charts [Phillips et al., 2012] to derive new heuristic values that encourage the MAPF methods to travel paths that include the edges of the motorways, avoiding head-to-head collisions between the agents and achieving consistency and predictability of their movements. Thus, for example, in a warehouse system in Kiva, we can design high values that cover the narrow passages between the 2 locations as shown in the images.

sections.heading: 5 Dealing with Imperfect Plan-Execution Capabilities
sections.text: State-of-the-art MAPF or TAPF systems can find collision-free paths for hundreds of agents optimally or with user-provided sub-optimum guarantees in reasonable computational time, even in crowded and confined environments, such as Kiva warehousing systems. However, agents often have imperfect plan execution capabilities and are unable to perfectly synchronize their movements, which can lead to frequent and time-consuming rescheduling. Therefore, we have proposed a framework that makes efficient the use of a simple time network to topostat an MAPF solution to create a plan execution plan that works for non-holonomic robots, takes into account their maximum translation and rotation speeds, provides a guaranteed safety distance between them, and exploits gap (defined as the difference between the latest and earliest site entry times) to absorb imperfect plan execution and, in many cases, avoid Umplantic Umplantations in addition to the robotic [APF was applied in 2016].

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We discussed four areas of research that address problems that arise when generalizing MAPF methods to real-world scenarios and exploiting either the problem structure or existing MAPF methods. Our aim was to identify interesting areas of research for researchers working in the field of MAPF.

sections.heading: 7 Acknowledgments
sections.text: Research at USC has been supported by ARL under grant numbers W911NF-14-D-0005, ONR under grant numbers N00014-14-1-0734 and N00014-09-1-1031, NASA via Stinger Ghaffarian Technologies, and NSF under grant numbers 1409987 and 1319966. The views and conclusions contained in this document are those of the authors and should not be interpreted to represent, either explicitly or implicitly, the official policies of funding organizations, agencies, or the U.S. government.

We have recently studied various issues that arise when generalizing MAPF to real-world scenarios, including Kiva (Amazon Robotics) warehouse systems [Wurman et al., 2008] (Figure 1) and autonomous aircraft towing vehicles [Morris et al.
, 2008] (Figure 1) and autonomous aircraft towing vehicles [Morris et al., 2016].
We have also developed an optimal TAPF method that scales to dozens of teams and hundreds of agents [Ma and Koenig, 2016].
We have formulated the package-exchange robot routing (PERR) problem as a first attempt to tackle more general transportation problems where payload transfers are allowed [Ma et al., 2016].

We have exploited the problem structure of given MAPF instances in two stages: In the first stage, we have developed a scheme for finding paths for the agents that include many edges from user-provided highways, which achieves consistency and predictability of agent motions [Cohen et al., 2015].
In the second stage, we have developed methods that automatically generate highways [Cohen et al., 2016].

We have developed a framework that efficiently postprocesses the output of a MAPF method to create a plan-execution schedule that can be xecut d by real-world multi-robot systems [Hönig et al., 2016].
It can be solved optimally in polynomial time with flow-based MAPF methods [Yu and LaValle, 2013a; Turpin et al., 2014].
It can be solved optimally in polynomial time with flow-based MAPF methods [Yu and LaValle, 2013a; Turpin et al., 2014].
The state-of-the-art optimal TAPF method, called the Conflict-Based Min-Cost Flow [Ma and Koenig, 2016], combines search and flow-based MAPF methods.

In reality, the packages can often be tr nsferred among agents, which results in more general transportation problems, for example, ride-sharing with passenger transfers [Coltin and Veloso, 2014] and package delivery with robots in offices [Veloso et al.

In reality, the packages can often be tr nsferred among agents, which results in more general transportation problems, for example, ride-sharing with passenger transfers [Coltin and Veloso, 2014] and package delivery with robots in offices [Veloso et al., 2015].
We have formulated PERR as a first step toward understanding these problems [Ma et al., 2016].
This motivates us to exploit the problem structure of given MAPF instances and design a scheme that encourages agents to move along user-provided sets of edges (called highways) [Cohen et al., 2015].

We use highways in the context of a simple inflation scheme based on the ideas behind experience graphs [Phillips et al., 2012] to derive new heuristic values that encourage MAPF methods to return paths that include the edges of the highways, which avoids head-to-head collisions among agents and achieves consistency and predictability of their motions.

Therefore, we have proposed a framework that makes use of a simple temporal network to postprocess a MAPF solution efficiently to create a planexecution schedule that works for non-holonomic robots, takes their maximum translational and rotational velocities into account, provides a guaranteed safety distance between them and exploits slack (defined as the difference of the latest and earliest entry times of locations) to absorb imperfect plan executions and avoid time-intensive replanning in many cases [Hönig et al., 2016].

metadata.abstractText: Multi-agent path finding (MAPF) is well-studied in artificial intelligence, robotics, theoretical computer science and operations research. We discuss issues that arise when generalizing MAPF methods to real-world scenarios and four research directions that address them. We emphasize the importance of addressing these issues as opposed to developing faster methods for the standard formulation of the MAPF problem.
